creator: sdgoldst@mailandnews.com
text:
Perfoming a VSS Get with no files checked out works okay.

I then check out a file and try again.  The build fails due to the checked out 
file being writable.

Here is the code that I used:

<target name="getsource" depends="init">
          <vssget localpath="${srcDir}"
                  recursive="true"
                  vsspath="${vssSrcDir]"
                  writable="false"/>
</target>

During the execution of the task, the following message is printed out when it 
reaches the checked out file:

"A writable copy of [filename] already exists"

The task continues, but the results is "Build Failed".

I expect the task to skip over this file as it does, but to not end in a failed 
build.

creator: nigel.magnay@parsec.co.uk
text:
I think this may be the correct behaviour -

If I do (from the command line)
ss get $/Project -R

and one of the subdirectories contains a file that is not read-only, it does 
indeed report that a writable copy exists and continues.

However, it also does not overwrite the file, and sets the errorlevel to 100. 
Since the file has not been overwritten, the get (getlatest) has not completed 
successfully - your directory does not contain the 'latest' version of the code
as you would expect - thus I'm not sure that this is a bug.

One workaround if you need to do this is to do a checkin immediately beforehand.

creator: bodewig@apache.org
text:
vss is signaling an error to Ant and therefore the build fails.

Maybe vssget (and others) should get a failonerror attribute?  Degrading to
enhancement.

With our current project, I am running into the same issue.  I understand that 
ss.exe returns an error code of 100 and that may be an oversight on the part of 
sourcesafe.  Perhaps the ant task could parse out the message and conditionally 
ignore "xxxx already exists" based on a property that can be set?  From a 
process point of view, the reason to have the build is so that a developer may 
extract the most up to date files and compile his checked out file with the 
build to verify that he does not break the build PRIOR to checking his code 
in.  If the developer is required to check-in his code prior to his own build 
verification, it would defeat the point of the process.
